bibl.title: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Albert E. Truby, November 19, 1948

div1.p: Kean has attempted to identify the persons in the photographs from Truby, some of whom he describes. Kean discusses his large accumulation of personal papers and books, which will be deposited at the University of Virginia after his death. Kean describes his recent illness and its effects. He lists new members of the Walter Reed Memorial Association, and expresses his apprehension that Hench might not finish his yellow fever magnum opus.

div1.head: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Albert E. Truby, November 19, 1948

opener.dateline:
2804 N STREET N. W.
WASHINGTON 7, D. C.
Nov. 19th '48

div1.p:
Your air mail letter of
Oct. 17 came on the 20th and the pic-
tures of Cuba came somewhat later-
There seemed to be no special hurry
about them, as Dr Hench was in Europe
so I have let them lie around while
I looked intermittently for a bundle
of photos and papers concerning the
7th army Corps which I had stuck
away some where- They would help
out the identification of the members
in the photo of Gen Fitzhugh Lee and his
Staff- I have not yet been able to give
the names of all, but think I could if I
could find a photo like that
which I think had the names on the
back- But I have not yet found it.
I have only one letter-filing case in
my den and it will not hold a 1/3
of the papers and letters which I have
accumulated in my long and somewhat
eventful career. The overflow are in
cartons and bundles stuck in here and
there in my small den I did have
a chestful down stairs but that has
been invaded and policed. I feel sure
that Dr. Hench has every thing pertaining to
Walter Reed & Yellow Fever, and the rest
await the inevitable day when my ashes
will go to the Monticello Graveyard, and
there will be a grand house cleaning-
I think that Cornelia and my son
Robert will send what looks of value
to the admirable Library at the Univ. of Va-
which has been most friendly in offer-
ing house room to my books and papers
with the understanding, which I from time
to time repeat, that they are requested to
burn what they do not want.

Well to go back to the pictures, Cornelia
said they had to go on to Dr. Hench as
she was afraid something might happen
to them, and she kindly offered to
pack them up and ship them by express
to Rochester Minn. if I would note on the
separate envelope what I had to say-
II stated that most of the faces were
familiar but I could only attach the
proper names to about half of them and
made guesses of the rest, all but three-
C2
B5
I had a good chuckle at your naming
no 1. on the left as Kean: The face had a
certain resemblance to me, but I never
had that much stomach in my life, and
besides, his legs were straight and I had
a shortened left leg with a crooked knee
since 1891- Besides I was not in the pic-
ture, or on Gen. Lee's staff at that time.
I looked up in my diary which sustained
my memory, and gave me the dates-
Lt, Col Louis M. Maus was the chief Surgeon
and was there as big as life as no.3 I think-
I have not the photo infront of me as it
it packed and awaiting shipment by
express- I came to Cuba in Dec. 1898 as
Chief Surgeon of Gen. Keifer's 1st Division
VII A. C. But Maus was on the skids and
was mustered relieved on Feb. 6th 99. I succeeded
him and became Chief Surgeon of the VII A. C.
on 11th Feb '99 2 or atmost 3 weeks after the photo. was
taken-
J. R. K. to A. E. T- sheet 2-

2804 N STREET N. W.
WASHINGTON 7, D. C.

The date on the photo is Jan. 2/ the rest of
the date being torn off, but I think it was
twenty something- The figure 1. which you
thought was me was a Vol. Med. Major
named Fowler, from New York, who had
come to Jacksonville and reported to Gen
Lee- He was a good surgeon, and Gen Lee
attacked him to the Staff, I suppose tempo-
rarily, until a good vacancy presented
itself for him- He was a Major & Chief
Surgeon, and was not so easy to locate as
the Chief Surgeons of Divisions were all of
the Regular Med. Corps- (or Dept as it was
then-) The Lt. Col on Gen. Lee's left was O. E.
Wood Chief Commissary- You gave him some
other name- He and his wife were in the
mess with the Lees in 1900 in Marianao, but
neither Gen Lee nor I had much use for him-
When the staff attended one of the funerals of
6
a yellow fever victim, an officer, altho we
were mounted, he could not attend for
fear of catching it! Cornelia knew some
of the staff- She came down as Miss Knox
to visit the Michies and Slocums who lived
together in a fine house on the Calsada Real
near the little plaza in front of the Toledo
Casa where was Gen Lee's Hdqrs- I could
not recognize major Edmonds who died of y. f.
and from whom I think I got my case-
But Major Michie and the Gen's two aides
Lieuts Fitz Lee and Sartoris, and several
others, Major Russell Harrison among them, I
could identify readily- My memory for
names has deteriorated since my 6 weeks
illness at Walter Reed Hospital in the
spring- I did not have a stroke, but had
a congestion of the brain from suddenly
increased blood pressure- After a week
of treatment it came back practically to
normal but did some damage as I
cannot remember names as well, even
the names of familiar flowers- one day
I can remember them and the next day
I cannot- I had a postal from
Dr. Hench this a. m. from Hamberg, Germany
He said that Mrs Hench was going
to Paris and then home- He has a
job of inspections in Germany which will take
him 2 to 3 weeks & then he will return
It was dated Nov. 14. so he will see
starting home about Dec. 1st I hope
that he has had some rest while
abroad- I am in constant fear that
he will break down before he gets his
magnum opus written- We had a
good meeting of the Walter Reed memo
Assn-
C2
B5
last Monday- We elected Dr. Soper a
member to replace Admiral Still who
died last week, after a long illness-
Dr. Soper is Director of the Pan Amer. San.
Bureau and you will recall him as the
Chairman who introduced the speakers
at the meeting of May 12th- Col. Liles
nominated him- Surg. Gen Bliss was
also elected as an ex officio-member-increasing
the number of members from 11 to 12-
Gen. Ireland was not able to attend-
I think now he cannot walk alone
He has steel splints on both legs now.
Our little part time maid is about
to go so I must close, to get this
in the mail- The bundle of pictures
by express-
went off an hour ago. Dr. Hench wanted
them to got by registered mail, but
that is very inconvenient for us-
Affectionate regards to your Bormie - & your self
